title: My Child Keeps Forgetting Multiplication Tables – What Works
description: Effective strategies for helping children who struggle to remember their times tables despite repeated practice.

content.intro: You've practiced, used flashcards, sung songs – but 7×8 still doesn't stick. Why won't multiplication tables stay in your child's memory?

sections.text: Why Multiplication Tables Are Hard to Remember

items: No meaningful pattern to some facts

sections.text: The Real Problem: How We Teach Times Tables
Traditional methods focus on rote memorization – repeating facts over and over hoping they stick. This works for some kids, but for many:

items: Facts memorized in isolation don't connect to understanding
Without understanding, facts are easily confused
Stress and pressure make memory worse

sections.text: Most kids know 2s, 5s, and 10s easily. Use these as anchors. For 6×7, think 5×7=35, plus one more 7 = 42.

items: Doubles: Square numbers are just doubles (6×6 = 6 doubled 6 times)

sections.text: Arrays, area models, and manipulatives help kids see what multiplication means. Understanding aids memory.
Instead of cramming all facts, review each fact at increasing intervals. Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, Day 14. This builds long-term memory.
Real-world use helps memory: "We have 8 people and each needs 7 cookies. How many do we need?" Context creates hooks for memory.
The trickiest facts for most kids: 6×7, 6×8, 7×8, 8×8. Focus extra attention on these, and make sure all other facts are solid first.
Consistency beats intensity. Five minutes daily is better than 30 minutes once a week.

faq.question: What grade should kids know multiplication tables?
faq.answer: By end of 3rd grade (US), most students should have multiplication facts memorized. But many take longer, and that's okay if they're making progress.

faq.question: Are songs and rhymes effective?
faq.answer: For some kids, yes. Musical memory is powerful. But be aware that some kids memorize the song without being able to use the facts flexibly. Combine with other methods.

faq.question: Should I use flashcards?
faq.answer: They can help, but don't make them stressful. Mix in easy facts to build confidence. Keep sessions short. And use them alongside understanding-based approaches.

cta.text: SoroKid uses adaptive practice to build multiplication fluency – identifying weak spots and reinforcing until facts stick.
